Physical Chemical Biological Ergonomic Safety
Hazard Source Health Risks Prevention and Control
"Water contact with power transmission lines 
 Lack of grounding systems 
 Electric shock caused by working in high humidity locations 
 Electric shocks caused by standby power when main power is turned off for maintenance reasons 
 Bare wires" "Burns 
 Abnormal and irregular heart rhythm 
 Nerve disorders 
 Involuntary Muscle Contraction (spasm) 
 Death" "Elimination or replacement: Use Ground Fault Circuit Interrupters (GFCI), fuses and circuit breakers to reduce the likelihood of electric shock 
 Engineering controls: Ensure the use of fuses and an adequate grounding system 
 Make sure all cables are intact and waterproof 
 Avoid electric overload
Administrative and PPE: Training workers on the risks of electric shock associated with using equipment close to water 
 Electrical installations must be reviewed and guaranteed by a qualified electrician 
 Never work alone so that in case of an electric shock, you have someone who can turn off the power 
 The power must be turned off when the equipment is handled 
 Ensure regular equipment maintenance 
 Place electrical hazard signs on equipment with risk of electric shock
"Constant exposure to noise emitted by vehicles and machines (boat engine, Oyster washing machines and high pressure washers) and water movements" "Temporary or permanent hearing loss 
 Inner ear injury (Acoustic trauma) from sudden very loud noise exposure 
 Ringing/buzzing in the ear 
 Physical and psychological stress 
 Annoyance 
 Rapid heart rate and hypertension 
 Sleep disturbance 
 Headaches 
 Interference in communication and concentration" "Elimination or replacement: Replacement for less noise equipment
Engineering controls: Build barriers that prevent noise from reaching the worker 
 Isolate the noise source in an insulated room or enclosure 
 Maintain tools and equipment routinely

Administrative and PPE: Using headset 
 Work Rotation 
 Intervals between activities 
 Wear hearing protectors 
 Medical surveillance to detect early signs of hearing loss"
"Exposure to ultraviolet radiation from the sun" "Skin cancer 
 Dehydration 
 Headache 
 Skin burns (first and second degree) 
 Cataract 
 Blindness 
 Insolation 
 Dermatitis" "Elimination or replacement: Working in covered areas and protected from the sun
Engineering controls: N/A
Administrative and PPE: Wear sunscreen, hats and sunglasses 
 Reduce exposure to sunlight with labor turnover 
 Perform skin examinations at suspect points"
"Damaged power supply 
 Faulty electrical equipment 
 Improperly discarded cigarettes 
 Incorrect use and storage of flammable products 
 Flammable gas leakage 
 Positive Battery Terminal Exposed on Boats" "Burns 
 Disability as a result of serious sequelae 
 Death" "Elimination or replacement: Replace flammable substances 

Engineering controls: Cover terminals to avoid sparks 
 Keep spark sources away from oxygen tanks and clothing 
 Install sprinkler suppression systems and exhaust fans 
 Regular maintenance of electrical equipment 

Administrative and PPE: No smoking around sources of fires and explosions 
 Provide designated smoking area and enforce proper extinguishing of smoking materials 
 Good housekeeping to avoid clutter 
 Ensure safe use and storage of chemical substances 
 Training and signaling 
 Detect and repair leaks 
 Have fire extinguishers and check expiration dates"
"Intense exposure to the sun at very high temperatures because of outdoor work 
 Long exposure to very low temperatures, wind, rain and water" High temperature 
 Insolation 
 Sunburns 
 Dehydration 
 Heat rashes, swelling, cramps and exhaustion 
 Heat stroke
 Low Temperature 
 Hypothermia 
 Frostbite 
 Chilblain "Elimination or replacement: High temperature: Working in covered areas; avoid working in extremely hot environments Low temperature: Avoid working in extremely cold environments
Engineering controls: High temperature: automation and mechanization of tasks; ventilation and air conditioning, installing exhaust fans; insulating hot surfaces; shielding Low temperature: Thermal insulation
Administrative and PPE: High temperature:Rotation of work; shorten exposure duration and use frequent rest breaks; Intervals for fluid intake avoiding dehydration at elevated temperatures; train workers in recognition of symptoms of heat exposure; wear sunscreens, caps or hats; wear loose clothing that will allow sweat evaporation 
 Low temperature: Intervals for the ingestion of hot drinks avoiding the consequences of low temperatures; Stay dry; keep active; rotation of work; train workers in recognition of symptoms of low temperature exposure; dress in layers of warm clothing including water proof and wind resistant wear
"Exposure during the occurrence of rainfall 
 Exposure to seawater, tanks and ponds 
 Exposure to water used in cleaning and damp locations" "Skin disease (irritant dermatitis) 
 Slips, trips and falls" "Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: Building barriers that avoid direct contact with moisture
Administrative and PPE: Intervals between activities 
 Minimize wet work to less than 2 hours 
 Wear personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves, boots, clothing and overalls"
"Earth moving and dust forming jobs 
 Improper care of equipment 
 Precarious maintenance of boat engines" "Fainting 
 Dizziness 
 Skin and respiratory irritation" "Elimination or replacement: N/A 
 Engineering controls: Detect and repair leaks
Administrative and PPE: Use personal protective equipment (PPE) such as rubber gloves and respiratory protection mask for dust and gases 
 Replace chemicals with less toxic products 
 Reduce exposure time 
 Raising workers' awareness in the workplace 
 Use mechanical spreader 
 Signaling"
"Substances for preparation and correction of ponds 
 Products used in harvesting activities 
 Contact with limestone, hydrogen peroxide, sodium metabisulfite, backpack sprays and sprayers manually 
 Handling corrosive substances" "Burns 
 Irritation of the skin and respiratory tract 
 Premature aging 
 Anxiety 
 Depression 
 Memory loss 
 Poisoning 
 Teratogenesis (formation and development in the uterus of abnormalities leading to malformations - only in women) 
 Genetic disorder 
 Cancer 
 Death" "Elimination or replacement: Replace toxic or lethal products
Engineering controls: Chemicals should be stored properly in well-ventilated areas and away from reactive substances 
 Detect and repair leaks 
 Install sprinkler suppression systems 
 Mechanical equipment that reduces contact with chemical agents
Administrative and PPE: Personal protective equipment (PPE) such as: Closed-toe shoes, Nitrile gloves, Goggles and appropriate masks 
 Training 
 Do not use pesticides or herbicides to avoid intoxication or contamination of water 
 Signaling"
"Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is the ability of a microorganism (like bacteria, viruses, and some parasites) to stop an antimicrobial (such as antibiotics, antivirals and antimalarials) from working against it. As a result, standard treatments become ineffective, infections persist and may spread to others 
 Aquacultural workers: handling fish, molluscs, crustaceans - in ponds, lakes, rivers, wetlands and coastal or offshore waters" "Workers on farms and in slaughtering houses are at high risk of exposure to ‘super bugs’ that in some cases can resist as many as 12 antibiotics 
 Workers may carry these dangerous microbes home to family and community 
 AMR strains of E Coli, Staphylococci bacteria, Salmonella and Campylobacter are all pathogens in the food chain that pose risks to workers 
 Risk of contracting an AMR infectious disease through handling carcasses, infected work tools and raw meat products. The risk of contracting an AMR disease is greatly increased when a worker has suffered a skin laceration, cut or wound (however small) because many disease carrying microbes can only enter the body through roken skin 
 Other AMR diseases can also spread through inhalation and ingestion" "Elimination or replacement: Complete restriction of use of all classes of medically important antimicrobials in food-producing animals for prevention of infectious diseases that have not yet been clinically diagnosed; or for growth promotion 
 Do not use antimicrobials classified as highest priority critically important for human medicine for treatment of food-producing animals with a clinically diagnosed infectious disease 

Engineering controls: We recommend an overall reduction in use of all classes of medically important antimicrobials in food-producing animals 
 Use of quarantine and specific pathogen-free certified stocks, excluding vectors and external sources of contamination, and preventing internal cross-contamination
Administrative and PPE: Clean and disinfect boots- dispose of covers for shoes 
 Remove work clothes before leaving the farm 
 Wash hands thoroughly with warm water and soap 
 Dry hands with a paper towel 
 When hands are completely dry, disinfect with sanitizer and rub for at least 30 seconds 
 Always take a shower before going home 
 Change into clean clothes kept in an enclosed space 
 Avoid placing personal items, such as mobile phones, in production areas 
 Use appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE)"
"Handling or activities that promote direct unintentional contact with pathogens 
 Contact through contaminated water 
 Contact through interaction with animals" "Infections" "Elimination or replacement: Control and elimination of pests and vectors
Engineering controls: Control of vegetation around tanks and installations 

Administrative and PPE: Sanitation 
 Appropriate personal protective equipment 
 Vaccination"
"Venomous Handling fish with sharp teeth or spines that can cause cuts and stings 
 Poisonous snakes, and scorpions, spiders, caterpillars, mosquitos, wasps and bees present in vegetation and water 

Wild Bites and attacks of alligators and other animals (in regions favorable to the appearance of these animals)" "Stings 
 Bites 
 Deep cuts that may be infected 
 Intense pain 
 Wound-borne infections 
 Skin or generalized reactions (allergies), depending on the causative agent 
 Poisoning 
 Death" "Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: Control of vegetation around tanks and installations Setting traps to catch venomous animals and insects
Administrative and PPE: Put in sight emergency phones and local poisoning centers 
 Closed shoes and gloves for animal handling"
"Loading of excess weight 
 Awkward work posture during the handling of the animals in the harvesting process 
 Manual filling of live tanks with water 
 Loading fish from tanks or nets 
 Netting and lifting of fish loads 
 Netting, weighing and transfer of fish 
 Repetitive movements 
 Static loading (holding one position for extended period of time) 
 Load full fishing nets 
 Carrying sacks of feed without mechanical aid" " Low back, neck and shoulder pain 
 Repetitive strain injury (RSI) 
 Muscle aches and pains 
 Weakness 
 Stiffness 
 Fatigue" "Elimination or replacement: Use mechanical equipment to eliminate or reduce physical exertion 
 Use pulley, rail or crane to raise nets at the expense or transport loads
Engineering controls: Decrease tank height to improve lifting postures
Administrative and PPE: Maintain good posture and frequently changing 
 Where possible, reduce the weight of the load 
 Reduce the weight of high loads (such as fish nets filled with fish) 
 Take breaks 
 Worker training"
"Large fish kills 
 Rremote locations away from family 
 Abusive social environment 
 Sleep deprivation 
 High demand and low control situations" "Work-Related Anxiety, depression, and stress" "Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: N/A
Administrative and PPE: Worker education and training focused on the worker's quality of life
"Working hours longer than 8 hours per day or greater than 44 hours per week 
 Little rest time or intervals" "Tiredness and fatigue leading to poor attention and decreased productivity 
 Muscle aches" "Elimination or replacement: Maintain adequate working hours
Engineering controls: N/A 
 Administrative and PPE: "Better work organization"
"Working at night with low visibility" "Fractures 
 Drowning 
 Falls 
 Cuts 
 Vision Disorders 
 Sleep and tiredness 
 Stress and other psychological disorders 
 Increased propensity to accidents" "Elimination or replacement: Change shift to daylight hours
Engineering controls: Provide adequate lighting and backup lighting
Administrative and PPE: Limit night work to as few hours as possible"
"Tractor overturning 
 Miscellaneous incidents with machines, aerators and equipment 
 Machines without protective equipment" "Cuts and punctures 
 Crushing 
 Permanent disability 
 Amputation of limbs 
 Death" "Elimination or replacement: N/A 
 Engineering controls: Equip vehicles (including ATVs) with rollover protection structures (ROPS) 
 Regulate the rear PTO of the rotary implements on the terminal drive of the equipment 
 Install protectors in equipment and machines 

Administrative and PPE: Training to use machines and equipment 
 Use appropriate protective equipment 
 Avoid working alone 
 Avoid working while tired"
"Slips and falls can be caused by wet and slippery floors, tools left on runways, and discarded debris on the floor, such as oysters and open gutters 
 Falls of heights, floating or fixed platforms" "Fractures 
 Contusions 
 Dislocations 
 Potential of drowning of injured worker 
 Fainting and loss of consciousness 
 Drowning" "Elimination or replacement: N/A 
 Engineering controls: Non-slip floor
Administrative and PPE: Obstacle walkways 
 Keep the floor dry 
 Non-slip footwear 
 Map of risks and signs"
"Falls at sea or dams 
 Lack of use of the Personal Flotation Device (PFD) 
 Diving" "Drowning sequelae viz. Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, brain damage, chemical and fluid imbalances in the body, permanent vegetative state 
 Ingestion of excessive water through the oral and respiratory routes 
 Decompression illness 
 Death" "Elimination or replacement: N/A
Engineering controls: Install floating life lines or other devices to exit ponds and tanks coated with plastic or smooth or muddy surfaces
Administrative and PPE: Use of personal flotation device (PFD) such as lifejacket and emergency buoy 
 Training 
 Have knowledge of diving and swimming 
 Make sure on safety in diving and in doubles at least"
"Handling of syringe and needle in vaccination" "Local inflammation and severe pain 
 Infections 
 Influenza like syndrome with fever, muscle ache, and general malaise 
 Anaphylactic reactions with coma, dyspnoea, and confusion" "Elimination or replacement: Install automatic vaccination equipment
Engineering controls: Use corrugated table to immobilize the fish in the wavy groove
Administrative and PPE: Vaccine training 
 Use of Personal Protective Equipment such as anti-cutting gloves (high strength polyurethane) 
 Well equipped first aid kit"

General Checklist Management Checklist Workers Checklist
OK
Select the practices adopted at your workplace I use personal protective equipment such as gloves, caps, sunscreen, masks and lifejackets. The vegetation around tanks and facilities is often cut. Often pest and vector control is performed. Workplace is clean and organized. All electrical installations are waterproof, have use of fuses and proper ground connection. To avoid drowning, workers use buoys or lifejackets in contact with water. To avoid prolonged exposures, there are frequent breaks and rotation of workers. The workplace is flagged for risk. The transport of load by the worker is carried out in order to avoid excess weight lifting. People involved in the production process were sufficiently trained for their functions. Swimming or diving is a must for hiring in the workplace. Chemicals are applied using appropriate masks and gloves. Workers are advised to have some type of immunization (tetanus, hepatitis A and B, typhoid, influenza and / or yellow fever). In my work environment, it is possible to take breaks or change of position after long periods of activity. I use cut resistant gloves when handling equipment or sharp machines. Confirm
PhysicistActivity Spanish English Portuguese Hello World from section: %1$d ChemicalActivity BiologicalActivity ErgonomicActivity AccidentActivity GeneralScreenActivity ChecklistActivity ResultActivity
You work in a place x% appropriate! You work in a place x% appropriate! Check out some tips based on your markups to increase the level of health and safety: You work in a place appropriate! "You work in a place " % appropriate! Your highest score:
Always wear personal protective equipment to ensure your health and safety. Keep the vegetation always low to avoid hiding and abundance of animals Take pest control periodically to prevent insects, rodents and other animals or disease vectors in the workplace. Clean and organized work environment avoids damage to the workers health and influence on the quality of the company. Use of fuses, waterproofed and grounded electrical installations reduces the risk of electric shock. The use of buoys, lines or lifejackets in water contact activities prevents drowning and possible deaths. Jobs that require some type of prolonged exposure should be accompanied by frequent breaks and rotation of workers to avoid immediate or future health problems. Signaling in the workplace helps to prevent risks and should be used to warn of possible accidents. Use mechanical equipment to eliminate or reduce physical exertion. Use pulley, rail or crane to raise nets in the warehouse or transport loads. If the load carried is excess weight, the excess load must be removed in order to avoid future health problems and accidents. Personnel involved in aquaculture activities should use specific PPE and receive training and updates for their functions. Knowing how to swim or dive can avoid accidents like fatal drownings. The use of masks and gloves when handling chemicals is necessary to avoid poisoning and burns. Check the product instruction manual for correct use of protective equipment. Whenever possible, replace toxic or lethal products. Chemicals should be stored in a well-ventilated area away from incompatible substances. Most countries do not have a special regulation of vaccines for aquaculture workers, however, it is recommended that workers who have direct contact with animals and water carry out Tetanus, Hepatitis A and B vaccines, typhoid, influenza and / or yellow fever. Pauses, maintaining good posture or changes of position during periods of work are essential when tasks are repetitive or need to be performed in a specific position. Resistant gloves to handle sharp equipment or machines are recommended to avoid cuts and more serious punctures. There are high strength polyurethane gloves on the market that protect the worker against cuts and other injuries.
br.gov.rs.fepagro.aquasafe.preferences scorechecklist string_topics
O objetivo do AquaSafe é trazer melhorias para a aquicultua brasileira através da disponibilixação de informações sobre saúde ocupacional de forma ágil e de fácil compreensão. Com o desenvolvimento do aplicativo, informações científicas que estavam distribuídas em inglês e em diferentes locais da internet agora estão disponíveis facilmente e de forma off-line aos produtores, trabalhadores e demais interessados. EQUIPE
"Coordenadora:

Aplicativo AquaSafe
Floating Equipment Protection clothes Face protection Ear protection Sign protection Fire protection First aid Shock protection Chemical protection Diving protection
According to OSHA, effective controls protect workers from workplace hazards. There is a wealth of information to help employers investigate options for controlling identified hazards. Before selecting any control measure, it is essential to request information from stakeholders (workers and employers) on their feasibility and effectiveness.
Employers should select the most viable, effective and permanent controls. Select controls according to a hierarchy that emphasizes solutions including elimination or replacement first, followed by safe work practices, administrative controls, and finally personal protective equipment. Avoid selecting controls that can directly or indirectly introduce new hazards.
Occupational risk is the probability of occurrence of a health effect due to exposure to the hazard (OHSAS 18001). In aquaculture activities, workers are exposed to different hazards, which may be physical, chemical, biological, ergonomic and psychosocial. To eliminate, avoid or mitigate health risks related to these hazards, it is necessary to establish hazard control and risk management.
